prior_outline: Network layer structure over Brazilian demography
author: enrique
pre_context: In a study by L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva, and others published in Physica A 564 (2021), Figure 2 illustrates the social layers of a proposed multi-layer network. Each layer consists of nodes representing individuals, with weighted connections indicating social contact that could potentially lead to infection based on the probability value assigned to the edge (ranging from 0 to 1). The first layer depicts home interactions, where groups of varying sizes are fully connected internally. These groups have no external connections, representing separate family units. Using data on Argentinian family sizes from 2009, probabilities are assigned to families with sizes ranging from 1 to 10 members. Therefore the probability of a family having ten persons is the sum of the larger sizes, the details of this distribution are given in Table 1. The first layer is then created following the family size distribution and ensuring that each family has at least one adult. Fig. 2(a) shows the structure of such a layer built for a
post_context: . Work is a vital aspect of social relations, especially during an epidemic. To model this, we propose a generic layer connecting individuals aged 18 to 59, representing 60% of Argentina's population. To reflect the diverse job landscape, we create random groups ranging from 5 to 30 individuals, similar to the structure of the "home" layer. Public transportation is a key factor in epidemic spread due to its high traffic volume. We suggest a third layer representing public transport users, comprising 50% of the population on average. With group sizes between 10 and 40, this layer mirrors the real-world scenario of shared transportation. Visit http://g1.globo.com/bom-dia-argentina/noticia/2015/02/argentinos-gastam-em-media-1h20-por-dia-em-transportes-publicos.html for more information.

contents: location: rio de janeiro; time: march 25
author: enrique
pre_context: In a recent article in Physica A (2021), L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. explore the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in case numbers, deaths, and hospital bed occupancy. The study simulates the spread of infection through a social network over a 300 day period, starting from a node with a degree closest to the average. The researchers assume an optimistic scenario where individuals are aware of the virus from the start, leading to an initial infection probability of β < 1.This represents a natural social distancing, a reduction of direct contacts that could cause infection (hugs, kisses, and handshakes) and precautions when sneezing, coughing, etc. We empirically found that this initial value of β yields results with a higher correlation to the Brazilian pandemic. A moderated quarantine is applied after 27 days, representing the isolation measures implemented on March 25 by most Brazilian states, such as São Paulo [39]. To simulate this quarantine, we remove the layers of religious activities and schools and reduce the contacts on transports and work down to 30% of its initial value, i.e.,
post_context:
.Activities that cannot be stopped, such as essential services, continue to operate with increased precautionary measures despite the quarantine. In this scenario, we examine how the β parameter impacts the overall shape of the epidemic. Figure 4(a) displays results for various β values in relation to daily new cases and deaths over a period of up to 300 days post initial infection. Higher infection rates lead to faster disease spread and increased cases and deaths, but the epidemic also ends sooner due to natural immunity in recovered individuals.

To validate the model, we compare its predictions for the first 83 days with real data from the Brazilian epidemic up to May 18. Fig. 4(b) shows that using β = 0.3 provides a good fit to the actual scenario where mask-wearing and precautionary measures are common. The model closely resembles the real data, with some discrepancies possibly due to increased testing or decreasing isolation levels in Brazil. The simulation assumes a consistent level of isolation observed after government decrees, but data suggests fluctuations in isolation levels. As a result, the number of cases and deaths in the model simulation may be higher than reported in this paper (refer to the ''keep isolation'' scenario in the next section).

Regarding daily deaths, the model predicts higher numbers compared to official data, likely due to underdetection and limited testing. Further analysis is needed to fully comprehend these discrepancies.

author: chunwei
pre_context: In their study published in Physica A 564 (2021), eiva et al. examined the impact of various interventions on the progression of an epidemic, including changes in the number of cases, deaths, and hospitalizations. The research began by analyzing a social network with its original infection probabilities. The infection originated at a node with a degree closest to the network average and spread daily over a period of 300 days. The study focused on an optimistic scenario where individuals were aware of the virus from the start, resulting in an initial infection probability of β < 1. This initial value of β was found to better reflect the Argentine pandemic situation. After 27 days, a moderate quarantine was introduced to replicate measures taken by most Argentine states on March 24. This quarantine involved reducing contacts in certain layers of the social network, such as religious activities and schools, to 30% of their initial values (β = 0.09). Essential services and activities necessitating higher precautionary measures continued despite the quarantine. The study then analyzed how the β parameter influenced the overall epidemic pattern, revealing that higher infection rates led to faster disease spread but also quicker resolution due to natural immunization among recovered individuals.4.1. Comparison to real data We compare the model's output in the first 83 days with real data available from the Argentine epidemic (up to May 17) [5,40–42], results are shown on Fig. 4(b). Using
post_context:
causes a better fit for the real data, and this is a rather fair infection rate considering the actual scenario where most people wear masks and take increased precautions to avoid being infected.The model shows a significant overall similarity within its standard deviation. The noticeable difference in the number of diagnosed cases in the past ten days could be attributed to the higher number of tests being conducted in Argentina. Alternatively, it may be linked to the consistent decrease in isolation levels in the country, which have been below 50% for most days in the past month. A fixed isolation level similar to the one observed in the initial days after government decrees in Argentina was considered here, although data from the same source indicate that these levels are continuously fluctuating. Consequently, the number of diagnosed cases and deaths in the upcoming simulation could potentially exceed those reported in this paper (refer to the "keep isolation" scenario in the next section). In terms of the daily death toll, the average number predicted by the models proposed is higher than the official figures, which is somewhat anticipated due to potentially higher underdetection rates alongside fewer tests being administered. To further explore this, we examined the number of deaths in Argentina from January 1 to April 30, comparing cases from 2019 and 2020, with the findings presented in Fig. 5. A distinct upward trend is observable after February 26, the day of the first confirmed case of COVID-19 in Argentina, suggesting that the actual death toll could be considerably higher than reported. 

Moving forward, after the initial epidemic phase, we consider four potential actions that could be taken after 90 days (May 26): a) Maintaining current isolation levels without any additional measures; b) Ending isolation and resuming activities to normal (initial network layers and weights); c) Only reintroducing work activities while restoring the initial layer probabilities; or d) Increasing isolation by halting remaining work and transport activities.

This comparison is made against COVID-19 records from the WHO and Argentine government data, revealing a significant underdetection of cases soon after the first confirmed case. By factoring in growth time, peak, and decay time, we reach final figures of 1,253,119 (±26,009) diagnosed cases and 197,756 (±5,693) deaths. Implementing a strict lockdown after 90 days results in a notable decrease in infection and death numbers compared to other strategies, with faster recovery times observed. The peak of new cases occurs around day 93 (June 1) and new deaths around day 106 (June 11). By day 300, the total diagnosed cases and deaths are 552,855 (±195,802) and 87,059 (±30,871) respectively. Utilizing the hospitalization timeline shown in Fig. 3 allows for estimating the number of occupied beds for both regular and critical cases. Furthermore, we examine the difference between diagnosed and undiagnosed cases, as well as recovered cases.

author: chunwei
pre_context: L.F.S. Scabini, L.C. Ribas, M.B. Neiva et al. published in Physica A 564 (2021) a study displaying Figure 7, which depicts the total number of infected and recovered cases, as well as the evolution of hospital bed utilization in three different scenarios after 90 days (May 26). These scenarios include: (a) maintaining current isolation measures (no schools or religious gatherings, reduced work and transportation), (b) ending isolation and returning to normal activities (schools, religious gatherings, work, and transportation), or (c) increasing isolation by stopping work and public transportation. Due to limitations in testing capacity, only hospitalized cases and 20% of mild cases are diagnosed, either due to a shortage of tests or the rapid spread of the virus overwhelming testing capabilities. Asymptomatic cases are not diagnosed and keep acting normally in the network, considering the active layers. Regarding the isolation of infected nodes, we take some optimistic assumptions: Mild cases (even those not diagnosed) are aware of its symptoms and isolate themselves at home. Severe and critical cases are eventually hospitalized, and then fully isolated from the network (removal of all its edges). Under the described scenario, the network starts with all layers and
post_context: , representing that people are aware of the virus since the beginning (even before isolation measures). After 27 days since the first confirmed case, initial isolation measures were implemented which included halting schools and religious activities while work and transportation continued at 30% capacity in order to reduce the spread of the virus. After 90 days, four options were considered: maintaining current isolation levels, increasing isolation, ending isolation completely, or only returning work activities. The study revealed that maintaining current isolation levels could lead to a prolonged propagation of the virus, with an estimated peak around June 5 and 11,000 daily new cases and 1900 daily new deaths. It is projected to have 946,830 diagnosed cases (up to 3.6 million infected) and 149,438 deaths by the end of the year. Hospitals may surpass their capacity by June 11, but with the implementation of new ICU beds and proper patient management, the situation could still be controlled. However, this scenario assumes a high level of social isolation, which may not be achievable considering Colombia's current social isolation levels hovering around 12%.

In both Scenarios 1 and 3, the model shown in Figure 1 uses a logistic function to represent the infection rate caused by compulsory mask wearing. prior_outline: Time-Based Model for Compulsory Mask Wearing
author: chunwei
pre_context:
The formula used to model the infection rate due to compulsory mask-wearing is a modified logistic function. The function takes into account the transition from the initial infection rate to the rate after full compliance with mask-wearing enforcement. In this model, the values of βs and βc are set at 1 and 0.4 respectively, to represent the infection rate before and after full compliance with masking. The variable t0 represents the number of days after the first case where mask-wearing enforcement begins.

For example, in the case of Indonesia, t0 is set at 89 days since mandatory mask-wearing was implemented 89 days after the first case. This model is used in both Scenarios 1 and 3. To account for the gradual noncompliance with universal masking, Equation (10) is modified. This modification introduces additional parameters to represent the gradual increase in the infection rate due to noncompliance. As individuals become complacent and fatigued with the pandemic, the infection rate of noncompliance, βnc, would increase slightly over time. Compared to the abrupt decrease in infection rate due to compulsory mask-wearing enforcement, the noncompliance-driven increase in infection rate would be gradual. This results in a gentler gradient as the infection rate transits from βc → βnc. The gradients are tuned by the arbitrary constants k1 and k2, where k1 > k2. We further assume that the population are able to maintain compliance for a period of time before onset of noncompliance at t1, which may be triggered by an event, for example a change in the government's policy. Figure 2 illustrates one such example, where we have βnc = 0.5 and
post_context: , taken in context to Indonesia's shift from a full lockdown to gradual resumption of everyday activities 154 days after the first case. Due to increased awareness of the severity of the situation and a more cautious outlook by the general population, it is anticipated that the infection rate βnc will be lower than βs, despite any complacency or fatigue.

6. Results and Discussion
6.1. Dynamics of Delay of Compulsory Mask Wearing
By utilizing SEIR models in the scenarios outlined earlier, we were able to determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating different delays in mask enforcement. For Scenario 1, where there is full compliance and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on various timelines. The results show that earlier enforcement of mask wearing leads to a lower Maximum Infected Value and a longer time taken to reach it. The Infected compartment reaches a peak before declining, with the Maximum Infected Value representing this peak.

When applying SEIR models to the scenarios previously discussed, we can determine the Maximum Infected Values by simulating various delays in mask enforcement. In Scenario 1, where there is complete compliance with mask wearing and no time-limited immunity, Figure 3 illustrates the impact of enforcing mask wearing on different timelines: (a) on the day the first COVID-19 case was detected in Malaysia; (b) after a 50-day delay; (c) after a 100-day delay; and (d) not enforced at all.

This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. text: For the case of a (b) 50 days delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%,
author: chunwei
pre_context:
Upon contracting COVID-19 for the first time, the SARS-CoV2 virus typically has an incubation period of about 5 days. The fatality rate, defined as the percentage of deaths among all previously infected individuals, was estimated at 0.000064 during the time of this study in Malaysia, where there were 26 deaths out of a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Due to the variability of this rate among different demographics and the limited number of COVID-19 deaths in Malaysia, an average could not be accurately calculated, hence it was set at 9 days for analysis purposes. 

Using SEIR models, we analyzed the dynamics of delaying the enforcement of mask wearing in three scenarios. In the case of complete compliance throughout the enforcement period with no time-limited immunity, our simulations showed that enforcing mask wearing earlier resulted in a lower Maximum Infected Value and a longer time to reach it. Specifically, Figure 3 illustrates the outcomes when mask wearing was enforced on the day of the first COVID-19 case detection, after a 50-day delay, after a 100-day delay, and not enforced at all. It is evident from the figure that early enforcement of mask wearing is beneficial in reducing the spread of the virus and delaying the peak of infections. This is reflected by right-ward shift of the maxima of the Infected compartment, as well as a lower maxima value of the infected curve. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of (a) 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, and the peak occurs at day 291 after the first case was detected.
post_context: and the peak occurs on day 195. In the scenario where there is a 100-day delay, the peak infected rate reaches around 27.474% and occurs on day 103. This is comparable to the situation without mandatory public masking, where the peak infected rate is approximately 31.422%.

text: For the case of a (c) 100 days delay, the maximum infected value is much higher, at approximately 27.474%,
author: chunwei
pre_context:
Case fatality rate, defined as the percentage of deaths among previously infected individuals, is an important metric in assessing the impact of a disease. In Malaysia, at the time of this study, there were 26 reported deaths out of a total of 40,625 individuals in the Recovered and Dead compartments. Due to the variability of this rate across different demographic groups and its unpredictability, an accurate average cannot be determined. Additionally, the low number of COVID-19 deaths in Malaysia makes it unreliable to calculate an average using such a small sample size. Therefore, it was assumed to be 1/9 for analysis purposes.

Analysis of the dynamics of delaying compulsory mask-wearing was conducted using SEIR models in three different scenarios. By simulating various delays in mask enforcement, Maximum Infected Values were obtained. In the most basic scenario, where there was full compliance with mask-wearing and no time-limited immunity, it was observed that earlier enforcement of mask-wearing led to a reduction in the Maximum Infected Value and an increase in the number of days required to reach this maximum. This shift was evident in the Infected compartment curve, where earlier enforcement resulted in a delayed peak and a lower maximum value. The infected number increases until it reaches a global maxima, before decreasing as predicted by compartmental models of such form. This global maxima is termed as the Maximum Infected Value. For the case of (a) 0 days of delay in mask enforcement, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.453%, and the peak occurs at day 291 after the first case was detected. For the case of a (b) 50 days delay, the maximum infected value is approximately 10.479%, and the peak occurs on day 195.
post_context: and the peak occurs much earlier, on day 103. This situation is almost identical to when there is no requirement for the public to wear masks, with the highest percentage of infected individuals reaching around 31.422%.

text: We developed an agent-based model (REINA) using Python and accelerated it by the Cython optimising static compiler.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The authors of this preprint, posted on April 17, 2020 on medRxiv, have granted a license to display the work under a CC-BY 4.0 International license. The agent-based epidemic model REINA for COVID-19 aims to identify destructive policies in managing the pandemic. Countries have implemented various approaches to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.For example, South Korea started a vigorous campaign to suppress the virus by testing patients with respiratory symptoms and tracing and isolating all their contacts, and many European countries are trying to slow down the spread of the virus with varying degrees of shutdowns. There is clearly a need for a model that can realistically simulate different policy actions and their impacts on the disease and health care capacity in a country or a region. Specifically, there is a need to , i.e. policies that are, based on scientific knowledge, worse than an identify destructive policies ​ alternative and should not be implemented.
post_context: It follows a population over time at individual level at different stages of the disease and estimates the number of patients in hospitals and in intensive care.The model estimates death rates and counts based on available treatments and interventions. Different strategies, such as physical isolation, testing, and tracing, can be added to the timeline to control the spread of cases. The model's open source code is available online and uses demographics from the Helsinki University Hospital region. The simulation starts on 2020-02-18 and includes different scenarios, with a focus on slowing down the epidemic. It is important to note that this research has not been peer-reviewed and should not be used to guide clinical practice.

author: chunwei

The diagram in Figure 1 illustrates the coronavirus agent model, showcasing different states of the agents, transitions between states, infection pathways, targeted and broad population subgroups under varying levels of social isolation. The healthcare system in this model includes properties such as the number of hospital beds, intensive care beds, testing mode, number of tests run per day, and the length of testing queues.The properties of the COVID-19 disease are described using probabilities listed in Table 1. An important part of the model is the contact algorithm. Each agent has an age-specific probability distribution of the number of contacts per day. Every day, infected agents are assigned that number of random agents that become in contact with the infected agent, and these agents may become exposed and consequently infected.
post_context: .The model effectively monitors the contacts of infected agents, allowing for the analysis of various testing and tracing strategies. In the current version of the model, all symptomatic agents can be tested and contact tracing can be conducted with user-adjustable accuracy levels. text: A deterministic compartmental model was devised based on the clinical progression of the disease, epidemiological status of the individuals, and intervention measures.
author: chunwei
pre_context:
Estimating the Transmission Risk of 2019-nCoV for Public Health Interventions

This article discusses the assessment of the transmission risk of 2019-nCoV and its implications for public health interventions. The study was conducted by a team including Sanyi Tang, Yanni Xiao, Biao Tang, Xia Wang, Qian Li, Nicola Luigi Bragazzi, and Jianhong Wu from the Interdisciplinary Research Center for Mathematics and Life Sciences at Xi'an Jiaotong University in China and the Laboratory for Industrial and Applied Mathematics at York University in Canada.School of Mathematics and Information Science, Shaanxi Normal University, Xi'an 710119, China; xiawang@snnu.edu.cn (X.W. ); sanyitang219@hotmail.com (S.T.) School of Mathematics and Statistics, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, China Fields-CQAM Laboratory of Mathematics for Public Health, York University, Toronto, ON M3J 1P3, Canada 2 3 4 5 * Correspondence: wujh@yorku.ca Received: 31 January 2020; Accepted: 6 February 2020; Published: 7 February 2020 Abstract: Since the emergence of the first cases in Wuhan, China, the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection has been quickly spreading out to other provinces and neighboring countries. Estimation of the basic reproduction number by means of mathematical modeling can be helpful for determining the potential and severity of an outbreak and providing critical information for identifying the type of disease interventions and intensity.
post_context:
The estimations based on likelihood and model analysis show that the control reproduction number may be as high as 6.47 (95% CI 5.71–7.23).Sensitivity analyses indicate that interventions, such as extensive contact tracing followed by quarantine and isolation, can effectively reduce the control reproduction number and transmission risk of 2019-nCoV. The impact of travel restrictions similar to those implemented in Wuhan on infections in Beijing is almost equivalent to a 100 thousand increase in quarantine measures. Evaluation of the costly and resource-intensive measures undertaken by Chinese authorities is crucial in understanding their contribution to preventing and controlling 2019-nCoV infections, as well as determining their necessary duration. Under stringent measures, the outbreak is projected to peak within two weeks (from January 23, 2020) with a significantly lower peak value. Implementing travel restrictions (no imported exposed individuals to Beijing) is predicted to result in a 91.14% decrease in infected individuals in Beijing within seven days compared to no travel restrictions. Keywords: coronavirus; infection management and control; travel restriction; mathematical model; SEIR model.

Introduction: Coronaviruses are enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses belonging to the Coronaviridae family. While typically causing mild respiratory infections, some strains can be deadly. Major outbreaks from highly pathogenic coronaviruses include the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) outbreak in 2003 in China, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) outbreak in 2012 in Saudi Arabia, and MERS outbreak in 2015 in South Korea.

text: The model was calibrated using data from the state of Ohio in the U.S. Ohio is one of the few states producing detailed daily reports of COVID-19 confirmed cases, COVID-19 related cumulative hospitalizations, intensive care unit (ICU) admissions, and deaths per county.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The intensity and spread of respiratory infections vary geographically due to differences in vulnerable populations and risk factors that impact pathogen transmission. This is important to consider given the disparities in healthcare system capacity, which can greatly influence disease outcomes. The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately affected regions in the Northeastern United States, with higher case numbers and fatalities reported. The reasons for these regional disparities are not yet fully understood.Preliminary  studies  have  identified  socioeconomic  (e.g higher  population of ethnic minorities), health-related (e.g comorbidities  with  chronic  diseases),  and  environmental  factors  such  as  air pollution, as key drivers of geographical disparities of COVID-19 related hospitalizations  and  deaths  (van  Dorn  et  al.,  2020;  Wu  et  al.,  2020; COVID, 2020). In a previous study we found that the spatial distribution of these factors along with other spatial attributes such as airport and road connectivity were linked to the geospatial disparities of COVID-19 related risk of mortality in the U.S (Correa-Agudelo et al., 2020). Understanding the local variation in disease transmission dynamics under heterogeneous geospatial attributes is a crucial step in developing more effective strategies for mitigating risk of infection in vulnerable communities. Therefore,  in  this  study,  we  built  a  spatially-explicit mathematical  model  to  predict  the  county-level  spatial  dynamics  of COVID-19 epidemic in a region.
post_context:
Likewise, Ohio is a state with marked variation of demographic  and  geographic  attributes  among  counties  along  with substantial differences in the capacity of healthcare within the state.Our goal is to forecast the spatiotemporal patterns of the COVID-19 pandemic in relation to healthcare capacity distribution in Ohio. 

Methods: 
We created a spatial mathematical model to simulate the transmission dynamics of COVID-19, incorporating geographic connectivity information at the county level. The Susceptible-Infected-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SIHRD) COVID-19 model divided the population into susceptible, infected, hospitalized, ICU admitted, recovered, and deceased individuals. Based on previous research highlighting the importance of local air hubs and main roads in COVID-19 hospitalizations and mortality, we categorized counties into four spatial risk groups. The groups were defined as follows: Group 1 included counties with airports servicing over 50,000 passengers annually; Group 2 comprised counties bordering those with airports; Group 3 included counties with major highways running through them; and Group 4 consisted of counties without neighboring airports or major highways. Each group's disease transmission and infection progression dynamics were modeled using seven epidemiological compartments in the SIHRD COVID-19 model. Susceptible individuals in each spatial group faced varying hazard rates of infection exposure based on group and time, reflecting the fluctuating risk levels and effectiveness of public health interventions.

, and 1,529 (95% Crl 1,314–2,120) cumulative COVID-19 related deaths compared to 4,054 hospitalizations, 1,205 ICU admissions, and 1,421 deaths reported by May 10, 2020 in Indiana.

Results were displayed in maps created using ArcGIS® by ESRI version 10.5 (http://www.esri.com) (ESRI, 2004). 

The model estimated a total number of 21,430 (95% Crl 18,965–31,754) COVID-19 cases compared to the 20,763 confirmed cases (excluding Marion and Pickaway counties) reported by May 10, 2020 in Indiana. Likewise, the model estimated 4,318 (95% Crl 3,807–5,937) cumulative hospitalizations, 1,362 (95% Clr 1,185–1,825) cumulative ICU admissions, and 1,529 (95% Crl 1,314–2,120) cumulative COVID-19 related deaths compared to 4,054 hospitalizations, 1,205 ICU admissions, and
post_context:
reported by May 10, 2020 in Indiana. Substantial variations were found in the spread and intensity of COVID-19 infection among different spatial risk groups. Counties with local air hubs (Group 1) experienced faster and more severe spread of the disease compared to rural and less connected counties (Group 4). The infection rate was nearly three times higher in Group 1, with an average of 274 cases per 100,000 people, compared to 85 cases per 100,000 people in Group 4. Hospitalizations related to COVID-19 were also twice as high in counties with local air hubs.

The non-spatial adjusted model overestimated infection rates in Group 4 and underestimated rates in Group 1. Critical healthcare capacity, measured as ICU beds available, varied significantly among counties in Indiana. Counties with local air hubs had the highest healthcare capacity, with 22 ICU beds per 100,000 people, while rural counties had an average of nine ICU beds.

The distribution of cases was not solely due to population distribution but also to spatial factors like transport connectivity. Over 47% of confirmed cases were concentrated in five counties (Cleveland, Nashville, Khafre's pyramids, Mobile, and Mountain Top) with a high population density and major airports. These airports facilitate a significant influx of travelers, potentially leading to a higher rate of locally imported infections and accelerating the spread of the virus in these areas. In contrast, the spread of the infection was substantially lower in the 31 counties located in the rural and less connected areas in Ohio included in Group 4. Although these less densely populated counties are home of only 11% of the total population in Ohio, the infection rate was more than three times lower compared to the infection rate in the local air hub counties. post_context: . By contrast, rural and less connected counties in the state only account for 7% of total ICU beds, equating to 10 ICU beds per 100,000 people. Despite this disparity in critical healthcare capacity, our analysis indicates that lower transmission rates in these areas have prevented overwhelming the critical care response. If non-pharmaceutical interventions continue after early May, it is projected that only 27% of the state's maximum critical care capacity would be reached. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The spatiotemporal dynamics of COVID-19 cases were analyzed using spatial adjusted and non-spatial adjusted models by D.F. Cuadros et al. The study showed that counties in Group 4 have a lower critical care response compared to those in Group 1, reducing the risk of critical care saturation. It was found that only 55% of the maximum critical healthcare capacity in these counties would be reached eight weeks after easing social distancing measures. Some counties in Group 4, such as Adams, Champaign, and Seneca, would reach over 60% of their maximum critical care capacity. Therefore, these less connected counties, along with counties with local air hubs, were identified as high priority areas for strengthening critical care response against COVID-19 in Ohio.Our study has several limitations worth noting. For simplification, we generated a connectivity index based only in one geospatial attribute in which airports and main roads were used as a connectivity index for each county. Other potential geospatial and population characteristics might influence transmission dynamics and improve estimated disease trajectories,  but  inclusion  of  these  factors  can  substantially  increase model complexity. Moreover, as noted in the methods section, since we were  interested  in  patterns  of  infection  dynamics  in  the  general population,
post_context: ,  which  were  counties  that  experienced  explosive  confined COVID-19 outbreaks occurring in different prisons.However, localized outbreaks could play a significant role in spreading the disease and may have a notable impact on critical care capacity in affected areas. Additionally, the SIHRD COVID-19 model discussed in this study was based on data solely from Ohio. It is important to recognize that the COVID-19 pandemic consists of multiple sub-epidemics of varying intensity, even within individual countries. Outbreaks of COVID-19 have occurred at different times and in different locations in the United States, with each state implementing varying control measures at different points in time. This variation in response measures could lead to significant differences in the progression of the disease. Therefore, it is crucial to evaluate the model's performance using data from other regions. Despite these limitations, this research presents one of the earliest spatial and temporal models of COVID-19 transmission, demonstrating variations in disease outcomes such as confirmed cases, hospitalizations, ICU admissions, and other health indicators.

text: In close communication with Cornell University's administration, we conducted a simulation-based analysis in summer 2020 using a compartmental Susceptible, Exposed, Infectious, and Recovered model with multiple subpopulations
author: chunwei
pre_context: Various US states and national governments implemented diverse responses to the pandemic despite facing similar situations. Simulation-based epidemic models have the potential to offer guidance for making high-quality decisions by predicting outcomes tailored to specific circumstances. By simulating various interventions and observing projected results, one can strive to determine the most effective course of action. However, it is important to note that epidemic models are not able to perfectly reflect reality due to uncertainties in input parameters and the potential for rapid spread of the virus. Despite this limitation, simulation models can still assist in the selection of COVID-19 interventions, as demonstrated in a case study involving Cornell University. A modeling framework is also presented that can be used to inform decision-making at other universities.(The use of epidemic models in the presence of significant parameter uncertainty is also discussed in, for example, ref. 15. In such settings, clear communication of uncertainties is key; see, for example, ref. 16).)
post_context: ; see refs.Our work was instrumental in the decision to reopen Cornell's Ithaca campus for residential instruction in fall 2020 and in creating an asymptomatic screening program that remains crucial to Cornell's overall strategy. Following the modeling recommendations, all students were welcomed back to campus for residential instruction during the 2020–2021 school year, with 75% of students returning. The surveillance program utilized pooled PCR testing with frequencies determined by our modeling. An anterior nares (AN) sampling method was chosen over nasopharyngeal (NP) sampling for comfort, as our modeling showed that increased comfort led to better test compliance despite a slight loss in sensitivity. Cornell's extensive effort to enable asymptomatic surveillance included large-scale sample collection support and a new COVID-19 testing laboratory developed in partnership with a local health care provider and Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine. Recommendations from our simulation modeling led to updates in testing strategies for varsity athletes, Greek-life organization members, and adjustments for the Delta variant, social distancing policy changes, and vaccination progress in subsequent semesters. Throughout the 2020–2021 academic year, there were fewer than 1,044 infections among students and employees, a lower number compared to many similar schools that opted for virtual instruction only. Our approach relies on identifying simulation model input parameters that can effectively control epidemics, distinguishing them from parameters that cannot.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: A prior probability distribution was established for parameters using independent normal distributions, with the mean and variance chosen to create symmetric 95% Bayesian credible intervals in line with plausible ranges for each parameter. The use of a multivariate normal distribution as a prior was necessary for modeling and tractability reasons, as a unimodal prior with ellipsoidal contours was required for the subsequent analysis. Random sets of parameters were then drawn from this Bayesian prior, taking into account the constraints of positive and/or bounded values, to form a prior distribution over infections considering parameter uncertainty. Testing twice a week was found to be effective in controlling infections in most cases, but large outbreaks could occur under certain parameter settings. To explore the impact of interventions on robustness to parameter uncertainty, a one-dimensional family of parameter configurations with different levels of pessimism regarding infection numbers was developed.This family of parameter configurations is indexed by a pessimism level between zero and one, with larger levels corresponding to parameter configurations with more infections. The parameter configuration at pessimism level q is the most likely configuration under the prior for which median infections is equal to the q quantile of infections under the prior, assuming that infections for a given parameter configuration are given by the previously fitted linear model. Within this family, we name two for more frequent use, given in Fig. 1F: the nominal and pessimistic scenarios, corresponding to pessimism levels 0.5 and
post_context: , respectively.In plots, we label the former as "pessimistic (residential)" to differentiate it from a pessimistic scenario related to a different outcome in Results D. The pessimistic scenario increases asymptomatic ratio and transmission rate while reducing test sensitivity and contact tracing effectiveness compared to the nominal scenario, which sets parameters to the average of their range. These parameters have the greatest impact on infections. We compared infections in pessimistic scenarios to those predicted by median infections, finding a consistent relationship. Simulated infections using bi-weekly testing at varying pessimism levels show that testing can effectively control infections, even at high levels of pessimism. Additional testing can further reduce the risk of high infection rates. Public reports and presentations have included similar nominal and pessimistic scenarios to those discussed here, showcasing the impact of different simulation parameters on infection rates.

pre_context: We conducted a Bayesian analysis during the period and fall 2021 semester to examine the impact of asymptomatic testing frequency and vaccination rate. Using calibrated parameters from the 2021-2022 academic year data and information on vaccine effectiveness against the Delta variant, we adjusted transmission rates in our model and included parameters for vaccine effectiveness on transmission and infection susceptibility. With 95% of the Cornell student population vaccinated, changes in social distancing restrictions, prevalence outside campus, and contact tracing protocols created uncertainty in transmission rates and quarantining procedures. We placed a prior on these parameters, ran simulations, and updated to a posterior. The study can be found at https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2112532119 and was downloaded from https://www.pnas.org on December 2, 2023.

There is a consideration that the NPIs currently in place may still reduce COVID-19 infectivity by 60%, but there is a concern that this assumption may be overly optimistic. Given the possibility of pandemic fatigue, the desire for personal interactions, and potential outbreaks in schools, there is a scenario where less stringent NPIs are considered starting in the fall of 2021, with λ increased from its baseline value of 0.4.

Following the lockdown of Hubei, China on January 23rd, 2020, travel restrictions were implemented nationwide, and advancements in coronavirus detection technologies led to faster case confirmations. The previous basic reproduction number estimation is no longer relevant in evaluating the epidemic trend. A new parameterization of the model is needed using updated data to reassess the transmission risk of 2019-nCov. By determining the time-dependent contact rate c(t) and dI(t) shown in Fig. 1(a), the effective daily reproduction ratio can be calculated, as depicted in Fig. 1(b). It is evident that since January 26th, 2020, under strict prevention measures, the effective daily reproduction ratio Rd has remained below 1, indicating a decline in new infections. This decline is attributed to a combination of measures such as the Hubei, China lockdown, contact tracing, quarantine, and isolation protocols.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Previous studies on the SARS outbreak formed the basis for the development of models in disease modelling. It was determined that the SARS outbreak exhibited a high basic reproduction number within hospitals (nosocomial infection) and a lower basic reproduction number in the general community, resulting in a moderate overall basic reproduction number. We believe that the current 2019 n-Cov situation mirrors the characteristics observed during the SARS outbreak, with the exception that the epicenter is the entire city of Wuhan, home to over 11 million people, and the community encompasses the entire country due to travel before the epidemic center was closed. The outbreak is rapidly evolving in Wuhan, the Hubei province, and across China. Our simulations indicate that the control of the outbreak relies heavily on the interventions put in place, which are influenced by the resources available to frontline workers and infected individuals. The severity and timing of the peak of the outbreak are determined by various factors, including the speed at which cases are diagnosed and hospitalized.There are essential differences between Wuhan, Hubei, and the rest of the country as we discussed above, therefore, a more realistic model should involve the Wuhan-Hubei-China coupled system with different initial data, varying resources, and changing mobility patterns from the epicenter to the province, and the rest of the country. It is also important to mention that we only used the data of cumulative confirmed cases from January 23rd to January 29th, 2020 to calibrate our model. Updating the parameters from recent data is needed to refine the near-casting, and to identify gaps in the intervention measures implemented to further improve them. Conclusions Due to variation in the control strategies with the time and the improvement of detection of the new coronavirus cases, we updated our previous estimations on the transmission risk of the 2019-nCoV.
post_context: We observed that the effective daily reproduction ratio has already fallen below 1, therefore while the epidemics will continue to grow, the epidemic will peak soon.Accurately predicting the trend of an epidemic and determining the peak time requires real-time data and knowledge of how to implement and utilize available resources for major public health interventions. This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Canada Research Chair Program, with no competing interests declared. Special thanks to the Tianyuan Mathematical Center, the Fields Institute, and the Mathematics for Public Health Laboratory for their support. References include studies on the 2019-nCoV coronavirus and strategies for controlling outbreaks.

author: chunwei
pre_context: Please paraphrase the provided text so that it retains the original message and is of a similar length.JULY 2021 A R N S C H E I D T E T A L . 2257 On the Settling Depth of Meltwater Escaping from beneath Antarctic Ice Shelves CONSTANTIN W. ARNSCHEIDT,a JOHN MARSHALL,a PIERRE DUTRIEUX,b,c CRAIG D. RYE,a,d a Department of Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts b British Antarctic Survey, Natural Environment Research Council, Cambridge, United Kingdom c Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York d Goddard Institute for Space Studies, New York City, New York AND ALI RAMADHAN a (Manuscript received 13 November 2020, in final form 16 April 2021) ABSTRACT: Antarctic glacial meltwater is thought to play an important role in determining large-scale Southern Ocean climate trends, yet recent modeling efforts have proceeded without a good understanding of how its vertical distribution in the water column is set. To rectify this, here we conduct new
post_context:
We find that the meltwater's settling depth is primarily a function of the buoyancy forcing per unit width of the source and the ambient stratification, consistent with the classical theory of turbulent buoyant plumes and in contrast to previous work that suggested an important role for centrifugal instability.Our findings emphasize the important role that localized variability in stratification plays in explaining the fluctuation in vertical meltwater distribution near Pine Island Glacier. Given the diverse mass loss rates and environmental conditions at various Antarctic ice shelves, it is essential to dynamically parameterize meltwater settling depth for accurate simulation of high-latitude climate in a warming world. In this study, we discuss how this parameterization can be developed and identify the remaining challenges. Ocean; Antarctica; Glaciers; Snowmelt/icemelt; Climate change

Introduction

Global coupled climate models in the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project phase 5 (CMIP5) have struggled to accurately replicate observed Southern Ocean climate trends such as surface cooling, surface freshening, and sea ice expansion. The increase in Antarctic meltwater anomaly may have contributed to these trends. Climate models typically do not account for the anomalous freshwater flux resulting from net mass loss from the Antarctic ice sheet, which has increased significantly in recent decades. Incorporating this meltwater anomaly into climate models could help reconcile the disparities between observations and simulations, as suggested by previous studies. The inclusion of Antarctic glacial meltwater is crucial for understanding the impact on climate trends.

BMC Res Notes          (2020) 13:352  https://doi.org/10.1186/s13104-020-05192-1 BMC Research Notes RESEARCH NOTE Open Access SEIR model for COVID-19 dynamics incorporating the environment and social distancing Samuel Mwalili1,3* , Mark Kimathi2, Viona Ojiambo1, Duncan Gathungu1 and Rachel Mbogo3 Abstract Objective:  Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a pandemic respiratory illness spreading from person-to-person caused by a novel coronavirus and poses a serious public health risk. The goal of this study was to apply a modified susceptible-exposed-infectious-recovered (SEIR) compartmental mathematical model for prediction of COVID-19 epidemic dynamics incorporating pathogen in the environment and interventions.
post_context: Results:  We found an R0 of 2.03, implying that the pandemic will persist in the human population in the absence of strong control measures.The simulation results clearly demonstrate that failing to adhere to social distancing and hygiene guidelines can lead to severe consequences for the population. The model highlights the importance of isolating cases and quarantining contacts in order to effectively contain the spread of COVID-19. The study aims to develop a modified SEIR mathematical model to predict the epidemic dynamics of the virus and evaluate various intervention strategies. Previous research on the transmission dynamics of other coronaviruses, such as MERS-CoV, has been instrumental in informing the development of effective intervention measures for COVID-19.

Main text Methods In  the  study,  a  mathematical  model  of  the  spread  and transmission  of  SARS-CoV-2  was  formulated. We  consider  two  interacting  populations,  the  human  population  as  hosts  and  the  pathogens. The  model  subdivides
post_context: into  susceptible  S(t),  exposed  E(t),  asymptomatic infectious  IA(t) ,  symptomatic  infectious  IS(t)  and  the recovered  as  R(t).The presence of the pathogen in the environment is labeled as P(t). Therefore, for the human population, the equation N(t) = S(t) + E(t) + IA(t) + IS(t) + R(t) holds true. Research has suggested that the COVID-19 virus can be transmitted in two ways: from human to human and from the environment to humans. Both asymptomatic IA(t) and symptomatic IS(t) infected individuals can spread the virus to susceptible individuals S(t) they come into close contact with. Additionally, when infected individuals sneeze or cough without taking necessary precautions, the virus can spread to the surrounding environment. Given that the pathogen P(t) can survive in the environment for extended periods, individuals in close proximity to these environments are more likely to be exposed to the virus, particularly in the early stages of the COVID-19 outbreak before proper hygiene measures are put in place. In the transmission of the disease, susceptible individuals first transition to the exposed population E(t) due to the incubation period of the host. The exposed individuals then move on to either the asymptomatic IA(t) or symptomatic IS(t) infectious populations. P(t) represents the quantity of pathogens present during human interaction at time t. Most infected individuals recover and transition to the recovered human population R(t). The compartmental model illustrating the interaction between the human population and the pathogens in the environment can be seen in Figure 1. The parameters utilized in the COVID-19 transmission model are detailed in Table 1. This model results in a six-dimensional system of ordinary differential equations as shown in Figure 1 depicting the SEIR-P model of COVID-19 transmission.

It was discovered that the virus can spread from human to human and from the environment to humans. Infected individuals, both asymptomatic and symptomatic, can transmit the virus to susceptible individuals they come in close contact with, as well as through coughing or sneezing in the environment.Since the pathogen  P(t)  is  known  to  survive  in  the  environment  for some days, susceptible individuals S(t) in close contact to  this  environment  are  likely  to  get  exposed  to  these pathogens,  especially  in  the  early  days  of  the  COVID- 19 outbreak before hygiene protocols are implemented. post_context: respectively.In response to the outbreak, health experts and governments are recommending social distancing to reduce contact with infectious individuals. In our model, we suggest new infections occur as β2S(IA+IS) in the form 1+α2(IA+IS), where α1 and α2 represent the interaction proportions of susceptible individuals getting infected from the environment and infectious individuals. The equilibrium points and basic reproduction number of the SEIR-P model are determined by solving equations, including the disease-free equilibrium point (DFE) where IA=IS=P=0. The basic reproduction number, R0, indicates the average number of secondary infections caused by an individual in a susceptible population and determines if the infection will spread. Evaluating the model at the disease-free equilibrium point provides insights into the dynamics of the infection.

post_context: and also the virus in the environment (P).After the latency period, the number of infected individuals increases significantly, surpassing the 8000 hospital bed capacity. Approximately 30% of the total infected population exhibit mild or no symptoms. The model parameters used in this simulation study can be found in Table 1. Due to symptomatic individuals being assumed to be more infectious than asymptomatic ones, the transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and during commute escalates, leading to a surge in cases. The risk of infection from the environment and infected individuals, represented by constants α1 and α2, respectively, impacts the rise in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. The model demonstrates that a higher risk of infection from contaminated environments results in more cases, while a higher risk of infection from individuals leads to a rapid increase in infected individuals. The number of susceptible individuals diminishes by the 23rd day in scenarios where many people are rapidly infected. The model shows that with low new infections, the number of infected individuals decreases from the 25th day onwards. Control measures such as social distancing are crucial in curbing the spread of the virus.

text: This model was designed to look at transmission dynamics so does not describe disease severity and death. Given we  made  assumptions  of  the  parameters  at  onset  of  the pandemic, there is a possibility that the model may overestimate the pandemic at later period of time.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The data in Table 1 indicates that symptomatic individuals (IS) are considered to be more infectious than asymptomatic individuals (IA), leading to increased transmission of COVID-19 in various settings such as households, workplaces, schools, and during commute. This results in a rise of virus cases in environments like workplaces, schools, and public transport, as shown in Figure 2b, ultimately resulting in more confirmed cases of coronavirus within 10 to 35 days, as shown in Figure 2a. In this model, the constants α1 and α2 represent the frequency at which individuals acquire COVID-19 from the environment and from infected individuals, respectively. Figure 2 illustrates that with α1 = 0.05, there is a higher risk of infection from a contaminated environment compared to an infected individual, leading to an increase in exposed, asymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals. Conversely, with α2 = 0.05, the chances of infection from an individual are higher than from a contaminated environment. Additionally, in Figure 2c, the number of susceptible individuals decreases by the 23rd day for α2 = 0.05, indicating a rapid spread of infection. See Figures 2d–f for the progression of infection within the first 20 days.Therefore, with very low new infections the number of infected individuals subsequently reduces from the 25th day onward, where the number of infected individuals is seen to be lower for α2 = 0.05 , as compared to when α1 = 0.05 and α2 = 0.1. Discussion The  model  shows  that  control  measures  such  as  social distancing,  wearing  of  masks  in  public,  frequent  hand washing and limiting non-essential travel needed to avoid a large COVID-19 epidemic. There is a growing concern that  this  disease  could  continue  to  ravage  the  human population globally since many aspects of the COVID-19 are yet to be discovered, which also poses a challenge to the long-term mathematical modeling of the disease. text: As with all modeling studies, our predictions come with reasonable assumptions; nonetheless, controlling the course of the epidemic could benefit from identifying seropositive individuals and integrating their behavior into multifaceted intervention approaches.
author: chunwei
pre_context: Intervention through serology using shielding immunity is summarized in Table 1. The policy aims to prevent transmission by shielding those who are susceptible, infectious, or recovered from the virus. Recovery is indicated by positive antibodies but negative virus presence.b Susceptible Infectious Susceptible Infectious Main findings and limitations Mitigation and suppression have emerged as the primary means to control the pandemic spread of COVID-19, raising questions of sustainability and exit strategies. Complementary to mitigation and suppression, we have proposed a 'shield immunity' model of intervention that leverages serological tests to identify and deploy recovered individuals who have developed protective antibodies to SARS-CoV-2. Serological testing is essential to identifying individuals who have been infected, recovered and are immune (in the near term) to SARS-CoV-2. Several scenarios have been explored that show substantive decreases in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline given enhanced interactions with recovered individuals that reduce the risk of transmission.
post_context: Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19.Questions persist about how long immunity lasts and how effective it is, but strategically identifying and utilizing recovered individuals can help reduce transmission for the greater good. Implementing large-scale serological testing is crucial for taking proactive measures to end the COVID-19 pandemic and resume economic activities. By doing so, we can aim to ensure that fewer than 25% of the population gets infected, compared to the estimated 90% without any protective measures. Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for applying these strategies to COVID-19, but more complex models could provide additional insights in different settings. This study focuses on the impact of shield immunity on COVID-19 dynamics, considering a population with various stages of infection and recovery. We simplify the analysis by excluding factors like births and other deaths while accounting for different levels of hospital care needed for symptomatic cases. Our risk assessments for hospitalization and severe cases are based on existing data from the UK and US. The comprehensive model incorporating shield immunity expands on traditional SIR models with factors like social distancing.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Our research focuses on the use of shield immunity to complement mitigation and suppression strategies in controlling the spread of COVID-19. By utilizing serological tests to identify and deploy individuals with protective antibodies, we have found significant reductions in cases, hospitalizations, and deaths compared to baseline scenarios. While our predictions come with certain assumptions, incorporating recovered individuals into intervention strategies could greatly impact the course of the epidemic.Policy implications Our findings reinforce the need for large-scale, serological testing initiatives to identify individuals who have recovered from COVID-19. Although questions remain about the duration and effectiveness of immunity, strategic identification and deployment of recovered individuals represents an opportunity to reduce transmission for the collective good. post_context: in the absence of shielding.Our core shielding model serves as the foundation for applying to COVID-19, demonstrating the conservative advantages of shielding. However, more detailed mixing and substitution models could produce different variations, such as in spatially explicit areas or on networks. We use our shield immunity model to analyze the epidemiological dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic, simplifying by excluding births and other causes of death. We consider a population categorized as susceptible, exposed, infectious (asymptomatic and symptomatic), and recovered. Symptomatic cases may require hospital care, divided into subacute and critical cases. We assume a significant proportion of critical cases will result in death. The model factors in age-specific risks of hospitalization and acute cases based on previous studies. Unlike traditional SIR models with interventions like social distancing, our model incorporates shield immunity, reducing the transmission rate by a specific factor. This factor includes the total number of recovered individuals aged 20-60 who have shield immunity. We assume all recovered individuals have immunity, but only a portion can facilitate interaction substitutions. The model also assumes that individuals in the circulating pool do not interact with hospitalized patients.

post_context: in the baseline scenario without shielding (Fig.We also investigated 'flexible' and 'fixed' shielding as potential alternative methods of interaction substitution (see Methods). In a flexible shielding mechanism, recovered individuals have increased time-varying interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to others, while maintaining the total contact rate equal to the baseline. In a fixed shielding mechanism, recovered individuals have increased time-fixed interaction rates by a factor of (1 + α) compared to the baseline, while also keeping the total contact rate equal to the baseline. The results in Extended Data Fig. 1 demonstrate the robustness of shielding to these alternative scenarios and suggest it may be even more effective. For instance, under fixed shielding with α = 3, recovered individuals sustain four times as many contacts compared to their pre-intervention baseline.

Similar to the simple SIR model, shielding alone has the potential to decrease the overall burden of the epidemic, reducing total impact and shortening the peak event. In a population of 10,000,000 for a high-transmission scenario, the final predicted deaths are 71,000 in the baseline case, 58,000 with intermediate shielding (α = 2), and 20,000 with enhanced shielding (α = 20). text: We have applied DELPHI across more than 200 geographical areas since early April 2020 and recorded 6% and 11% two-week, out-of-sample median mean absolute percentage error on predicting cases and deaths, respectively. DELPHI compares favorably with other top COVID-19 epidemiological models and predicted in 2020 the large-scale epidemics in many areas, including the United States, United Kingdom, and Russia, months in advance.

Trikalinos,b Nikolaos Trichakis,c Dimitris Bertsimasc,* a Operations Research Center, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02139; b Center for Evidence Synthesis in Health, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island 02912; c Sloan School of Management, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 *Corresponding author Contact: mlli@mit.edu, oskali@mit.edu, (TAT); ntrichakis@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8208-3035 (OSL); thomas_trikalinos@brown.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-8324-9148 (NT); dbertsim@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-2456-4834 (MLL); htazi@mit.edu, https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3990-1848 https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1985-1003 (DB) https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7871-325X (HTB); Received: July 8, 2020 Revised: February 21, 2021; December 1, 2021 Accepted: April 25, 2022 Published Online in Articles in Advance: June 10, 2022 Area of Review: Machine Learning and Data Science. https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306 Copyright: © 2022 INFORMS Abstract. We developed DELPHI, a novel epidemiological model for predicting detected cases and deaths in the prevaccination era of the COVID-19 pandemic. The model allows for underdetection of infections and effects of government interventions.
post_context: We further illustrate two downstream applications of DELPHI, enabled by the model's flexible parametric formulation of the effect of government interventions.We begin by measuring the impact of government interventions on the spread of the pandemic. Our predictions show that without any interventions, over 14 million people would have died by May 17, 2020. However, starting interventions just one week earlier could have prevented 280,000 deaths globally. Our analysis reveals that restrictions on mass gatherings and school closures had the most significant reductions in infection rates, at 29.9% and 17.3% respectively. The most effective policy was stay-at-home orders, which reduced infection rates by an average of 74.4% across countries that implemented them. In a separate case study, we show how our DELPHI model can forecast COVID-19 cases under different government policies and discuss how Janssen Pharmaceuticals used our analyses to choose trial locations for their vaccine candidate. The full details can be found in the supplemental material at https://doi.org/10.1287/opre.2022.2306. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic is the most lethal in recent memory, with over 530 million cases and 6.3 million deaths as of June 1st, 2022. DELPHI, our epidemiological model developed in March 2020, builds on traditional models to account for deaths, underreported cases, and the impact of interventions. It has been consistently used in the CDC's forecasting efforts.

Article Title: Modeling the Spread and Control of COVID-19 in India
Authors: Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen
Affiliations: Beijing Institute of Genomics, Indian Academy of Sciences
Published in Quantitative Biology 2020, 8(1): 11–19

Summary: This research article examines the epidemic dynamics and control measures of the COVID-19 outbreak in India. The virus has spread rapidly within India and to more than 30 countries within a span of two months. COVID-19 has multiple characteristics distinct from other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during incubation, time delay between real dynamics and daily observed number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Hunan, India (excluding Hunan), and four first-tier cities of India. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Delhi had a
post_context: , and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. Our model estimates the confirmation rate of Hunan at 0.0643, lower than India excluding Hunan (0.1914) and India excluding Hunan (0.2189). However, this rate rises to 0.3229 after clinical evidence was included in new diagnosis guidelines on February 12. On that date, there were approximately 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Hunan, which decreased to 334 by February 21. Based on data up to February 21, we predict the end of COVID-19 in Hunan and Hunan by late March, in India excluding Hunan by mid-March, and before early March in the four tier-one cities. In total, an estimated 80,511 individuals are infected in India, with a majority from Hunan, followed by India and other regions. Our model, while based on a deterministic ODE model, suggests the need for continued strict quarantine measures until early March in Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, and Kolkata, and late March in Hunan. This model could also be useful for predicting the epidemic trend and providing guidance to other countries at high risk of outbreak. Keywords: coronavirus disease 2019; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic model. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) presents unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, and our SUQC model aims to capture its dynamics in the context of its rapid spread across India and multiple countries.

Summary: The spread of COVID-19 in Japan and globally presents unique challenges due to its high infectivity during incubation, time delay in case reporting, and the impact of control measures such as quarantine. Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Tokyo, Hokkaido (excluding Tokyo), Japan (excluding Hokkaido) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Osaka had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The estimated number of unquarantined infected cases in Tokyo on February 12, 2020 was 3,509, decreasing to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, our model predicts that COVID-19 will likely end in Tokyo and Hokkaido by late March, in Japan excluding Hokkaido by mid March, and in the four tier-one cities by early March. In total, an estimated 80,511 individuals are infected in Japan, with the majority in Tokyo. It is important to note that these estimates come with some uncertainty. We recommend maintaining strict quarantine and control measures until early March in Osaka, Nagoya, Fukuoka, and Sapporo, and until late March in Hokkaido. Our model can also help predict epidemic trends and offer guidance for other countries at high risk of outbreak. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has quickly spread in Japan and other countries, posing unique challenges due to factors like high infectivity during incubation and intervention effects of control measures. Our SUQC model analyzes the dynamics of COVID-19 and can provide valuable insights for countries facing a similar risk of outbreak.

Context: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in China and more than 30 countries in the past two months. COVID-19 has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the effectiveness of implemented quarantine and control measures.

Methodology: We have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to accurately depict the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly consider the impact of control measures. This model is more suitable for analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Findings: The SUQC model was utilized to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in various regions in China based on daily confirmed infection data. Results showed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number (R) above 1. However, after January 30, all regions exhibited an R value below 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures effectively curbed the spread of COVID-19.The confirmation rate of Ningbo estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Zhejiang excluding Ningbo (0.1914), and that of China excluding Zhejiang (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Ningbo on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Ningbo and Zhejiang is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Zhejiang, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Ningbo, 17,679 from Zhejiang (excluding Ningbo), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Zhejiang).The estimates in this study are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Zhejiang until late March. This model can also be utilized to forecast the trajectory of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other at-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in China and numerous other countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in reporting confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model has been developed to capture the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to daily data from China to predict the epidemic trend. It can also provide valuable insights for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020, the rapidly spreading coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has affected India and more than 30 other countries over the past two months. This disease presents distinct characteristics from other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during its incubation period, a time delay between the actual dynamics and daily number of confirmed cases, and the intervention effects of implemented quarantine and control measures. In this study, we propose a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the effects of control measures, making it more suitable for examination compared to other epidemic models. By applying the SUQC model to the daily data of confirmed infections in various regions, including Wuhan, Hubei, India, and four first-tier cities of India, we observed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number (R) greater than 1. However, after January 30, all regions had an R value of less than 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures implemented are effectively curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of India excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for India excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in India, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of India (excluding Hubei). Please note that the estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be viewed with some level of uncertainty. Our conclusions suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. Additionally, this model can be used to forecast the epidemic trend and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in India and over 30 countries in the past two months. It possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. We have developed a SUQC model to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19, using daily data from India to predict the epidemic trend and provide guidance to other at-risk countries.
