pre_context: Data for assessing model performance is depicted in Figure 1B. The blue curve represents the model's fit, blue dots show predicted confirmed infections, and red dots show observed confirmed infections. Data before February 12 is based on nucleic acid diagnosis, with a switch to both nucleic acid and clinical diagnosis from February 12 to 14, and only total confirmed numbers from February 15 to 21. By comparing nucleic acid results with the fitted model, we can see a close match in trend. Adding clinical diagnosis after February 12 in Hubei increased confirmation rates, leading to a rise in confirmed infections. Despite this, a portion of total infections still goes unidentified. Using inferred parameters, predictions for total infected, unquarantined infected, quarantined infected, and cumulative confirmed infections in Hubei are made in Figure 1A, with an end time predicted at 147 days from January 28, 2020, and a total of 62,577 infected individuals. Stage I data from Hubei provides insights into epidemic trends assuming no strict quarantine measures, with the first 10 days (from January 20) used to determine parameters.The rest data points were used to test the performance of the model (Fig. 1C, D). As clearly seen in Fig. 1C, the predicted numbers of CðtÞ and IðtÞ increase dramatically, which are far beyond the observed numbers after Jan 21.
post_context: , and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1).The stark contrast between the predictions from stages I and II of Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen's data suggests that preventive measures and quarantines, such as travel restrictions, have been highly effective in controlling the epidemic outbreak. Following the recent implementation of stricter quarantine and traffic control measures in Hubei to curb the spread of COVID-19, we also analyzed stage III data from February 13th onwards. The estimated quarantine rate has increased to 0.6185, significantly higher than the 0.3917 estimated in stage II. This indicates a total of 49,510 infected individuals, accelerating the end of the epidemic. Similar analyses were conducted for stage I and II data in Hubei province (excluding Hubei), the rest of the country (excluding Hubei), and four major cities in China. The model predictions have shown high accuracy, revealing distinct differences in predicted infection numbers between the two stages, highlighting the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and control measures. Even with stage I data, Beijing's reproductive number is below 1, indicating a prompt and effective response to COVID-19. The confirmation rate in Hubei is notably lower compared to other regions, due to the high number of infected individuals overwhelming local resources. As predicted by the model, further steps are needed to improve confirmation rates and control measures in certain areas.

To model the dynamics of infectious diseases and artificial control factors, a set of ODE equations was established (Eq.1). In this model, infected individuals either go directly to being confirmed or indirectly through quarantine. The direct route can be seen as a special case of the latter with no delay time in quarantine. Therefore, the model was simplified by removing the direct path as shown in Eq. 2. Parameters such as the mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation (T) and the mean time delay from isolation to confirmation (w) can be defined from the SUQC model. The reproductive number of the infection is represented by R=α=g1. Parameter inference is usually based on the number of cumulative confirmed infections, C(t), as it is the only variable with daily observed data for model fitting. The initial susceptible individuals (S(0)) is assumed to be equal to the population size, while the initial confirmed infections (C(0)) is obtained from official reports.Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. post_context: .The numbers of confirmed infections in this time period may provide a more accurate representation of the natural characteristics of COVID-19, as confirmed cases were initially low and unstable before January 15 and were influenced by strict quarantine measures later on. Despite difficulties in accurately estimating the parameter α, various methods and data sets have produced estimated values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5. Fortunately, in our model, an exact value of α is not crucial as the overall infection rate, measured by the reproductive number R=α=g1, is sensitive to parameter optimization and can help balance any bias in α. By fitting the daily confirmed infection data to the model, we determine the values of free parameters such as g1, β, U ð0Þ, and Qð0Þ. The model provides an expected daily time series of confirmed infections denoted as ^C=f ðg1,β,U0,Q0Þ, which is calculated using a numerical method. We then optimize a loss function with the interiorpoint method in MATLAB to infer the parameter values. We find that our results are not significantly influenced by the initial values chosen for parameter optimization. It is important to note that the loss function may give undue importance to later data points due to the cumulative nature of case numbers, leading us to explore alternative weighted loss functions for a more comprehensive analysis of the epidemic progression.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on global public health and economy. V.C. Batista et al. from various Brazilian research institutions have conducted a study focusing on COVID-19, using agent-based simulation and epidemic models. The study, conducted at Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional, Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais (IFNMG), Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory, Federal University of Minas Gerais, among others, provides important insights into the ongoing pandemic.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for politicians and health authorities to strategize their response to the COVID-19 epidemic. The Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak, caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has been declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO). In Brazil, the first confirmed case was in February 2020, leading to a significant impact on the country. As of June 26th, there have been over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths in Brazil due to COVID-19. The virus has not only affected public health but has also influenced various aspects of life, including politics, education, economy, and environment. To combat the outbreak, implementing strict social distancing measures on the population has proven to be the most effective method, as suggested by numerous studies. Many countries are adopting such measures with varying degrees of success, given the complexities of their societies.

author: chunwei
pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into account means allowing the data at each time point to follow a probability distribution with a mean determined by the assumed model and a variance determined by the assumed probability distribution, where the variance might be influenced by the mean. Despite this, the lack of data presents a more significant challenge for modellers. A key factor that contributes to variations in model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) aligns with those predictions. Confirmed cases refer to individuals with symptoms who sought medical attention, underwent testing, and received a positive diagnosis of COVID-19 through DNA or imaging tests. In transmission models, the infected compartment encompasses all individuals who are infected, including those who show symptoms, those who do not, those with confirmed lab tests, and those who are misdiagnosed. Consequently, confirmed cases (data) only represent a portion of the total infected population (model predictions). The analogy of an iceberg best illustrates the distinction between data and model predictions: the entire iceberg signifies the complete infected population, with only the tip above the surface representing the reported cases. The submerged part of the iceberg symbolizes the infected individuals who evade public health surveillance and testing - often referred to as the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why could this pose a problem for modelers? In model calibration, it is necessary to adjust the total number of infectious individuals predicted by the model by a case-infection ratio in order to accurately estimate key parameters such as the transmission rate. This process helps to predict confirmed case data and determine important factors such as the basic reproduction number and peak time of an epidemic. The wide range of possible values for the case-infection ratio of COVID-19 results in a wide range of estimated transmission rates, leading to a variety of reported model predictions. This nonidentifiability issue, where different combinations of parameters can produce similar fits to the data but lead to significantly different predictions, is a common challenge in modeling. The way in which this issue is addressed during model calibration can greatly impact the reliability of predictions. Standard methods like nonlinear least squares may struggle to handle nonidentifiability due to their basic optimization algorithms. These algorithms aim to find the best fit for the data but may struggle to distinguish between the many possible global minima.

post_context: , and R denotes the confirmed cases.In the SEIR model, a hidden compartment E is included to represent individuals who are infected but not yet able to spread the virus. This reflects the biological reality of COVID-19, as the virus can incubate in the body for up to 14 days before individuals become infectious. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, when individuals are infected but not yet infectious, and the incubation period, when symptoms begin to appear. For SARS, infected individuals become infectious after about two days of showing symptoms, indicating a longer latent period compared to the incubation period. Evidence suggests that with COVID-19, individuals may be able to spread the virus before showing symptoms, but the exact length of the latent period is still unknown. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, but it requires two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and the initial latent population. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during model predictions. Our model calibration is based on newly confirmed cases data, which matches with the rI term in both models and therefore does not consider the death term in the R compartment. The systems of differential equations for each model are given, allowing for calibration using reliable data.

The SEIR model offers a more biologically accurate representation compared to the SIR model, but it comes with the challenge of having two additional unknown parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Transfer diagrams for both models can be seen in Figure 1, with detailed explanations of model parameters provided in Tables 1 and 2. It is assumed that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible within the prediction period of four months. When calibrating the models using confirmed case data, the death term in the R compartment does not impact model fitting. post_context: the initial population size E0 for the latent compartment E on January 20, 2019, and b, r, I0, and q ¼ 1=t.Since the mayor of Hubei announced on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population N in Hubei on January 20 to be around 6 million. We used uniform distributions over the initial range of parameters as priors for both the SIR and SEIR models. Posterior distributions were generated using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm to determine the best-fit values and 95% credible intervals for the estimated parameters. Comparison of the SIR and SEIR models revealed that the SEIR model resulted in a significantly higher corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AICc), indicating a loss of information compared to the SIR model. Therefore, our further investigation will focus on the SIR model. Additionally, our calibration results identified a linkage between the transmission rate b and the diagnosis rate r in the SIR model, as depicted in Fig. 2.

author: enrique
pre_context:
Technical, surveillance, or administrative data, as well as information from published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging when dealing with outbreaks of unknown pathogens that occur in real-time, such as the SARS outbreak in 2003 and the current COVID-19 pandemic. An alternative approach is to utilize more advanced inference methods and model fitting algorithms to narrow down large confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, which involved Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this objective.

Our baseline predictions for Beijing were calculated by sampling the posterior distribution to generate prediction intervals. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals derived from the Bayesian inference using newly confirmed cases in Beijing reported from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These predictions were made during the lockdown and travel restrictions in Beijing, prior to additional control measures implemented after February 7, 2020. The projections provide an estimate of the potential epidemic in Beijing if additional control measures had not been taken after February 7. Figures 4(a) and (b) illustrate the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Beijing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimation, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7th, the total number of peak cases could reach around 120,000, and the Beijing epidemic would not be fully resolved until mid-May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary greatly, with recovery times increasing based on the severity of the illness. In our model, we account for different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. Critical cases can either recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death rising with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious individual, with a probability denoted as β. For a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7, depending on various factors such as population size and age structure. The β value of 0.016 in Covasim was calibrated based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.The relative weightings of 10:2:2:1 were chosen to align with existing time-use surveys and studies of known contact types and to achieve a weighted mean similar to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. In a typical transmission scenario without interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions like physical distancing can modify the value of β. Individual infectiousness varies based on factors like age and time spent in different disease states, with viral load used to model differences in infectivity. Viral load typically peaks around symptom onset and then declines. Our model includes two stages of viral load, with the high stage set to be twice as high as the low stage and lasting for a specified duration. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability for an individual on a given day. The distribution of viral loads for individuals with default parameters is depicted in Fig 2.

pre_context: Covasim, a model of COVID-19 dynamics and interventions, incorporates varying recovery times for asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic, and severely symptomatic individuals. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or die, with the risk of death increasing with age. The transmission of the virus occurs with probability β when a susceptible individual interacts with an infectious one, with a value of β = 0.016 corresponding to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of 2.2-2.7. This value was calibrated to data from Washington and Oregon states and is currently the default in Covasim.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. In a typical transmission scenario without interventions, approximately 30% of transmission events occur in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each state, and infectiousness are accounted for by varying viral loads, with a model that includes an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. author: enrique
pre_context:
Therefore, it is important for the user to adjust this parameter to align with local epidemic data. If a realistic network structure is considered, such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary based on the type of contact. The default transmission probabilities vary, with higher values for households and lower values for workplaces, schools, and community. These values were chosen to reflect data from time-use surveys and studies of infections with known contact types. When combined with other factors, in an unmitigated transmission scenario, a significant proportion of transmission events occur in each contact layer. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can also alter the value of β. Additionally, individual differences in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectiousness are considered by allowing variability in individual viral load.

Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context:
, which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state.

The daily viral load determines the adjustment of the per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual on a specific day. Figure 2 displays the viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions among asymptomatic, pre-symptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the context; estimated proportions for Seattle can be found in [25]. There is conflicting evidence regarding whether transmissibility is reduced when the infectious individual is asymptomatic [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we offer a parameter that can be adjusted based on the modeling application or context, noting that some studies have used lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
